    Risk of bias for analysis 2.6 Adverse events: all grades
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 2.7 Serious adverse events

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    BLAZE‐1 (phase 3)

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and an appropriate analysis was performed.

    Data for this outcome was available for 1035 out of 1049 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was probably appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 2.7 Serious adverse events
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 3.1 Admission to hospital or death

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Weinreich (phase 1/2, 2.4 g)

    Participants were centrally randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were probably unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 446 out of 532 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    SAP and protocol not provided for this preprint. There is no indication that the outcome measurement and the results have been selected.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to the randomisation process, due to deviations from the intended interventions, missing outcomes, measurement of the outcome. There are some concerns for risk of bias due to selection of reported results.

    Weinreich (phase 1/2, 8.0 g)

    Participants were centrally randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were probably unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 450 out of 533 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    SAP and protocol not provided for this preprint. There is no indication that the outcome measurement and the results have been selected.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to the randomisation process, due to deviations from the intended interventions, missing outcomes, measurement of the outcome. There are some concerns for risk of bias due to selection of reported results.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 3.1 Admission to hospital or death
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 3.2 Adverse events: grade 3 and 4

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Weinreich (phase 1/2, 2.4 g)

    Participants were centrally randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 520 out of 532 participants randomised.

    There is no information whether measurement of the outcome was appropriate, but it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the previous protocol. There is no indication that the outcome measurement and the results have been selected.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to the randomisation process, due to deviations from the intended interventions, missing outcomes and due to selection of reported results. However, there are some concerns for risk of bias due to measurement of the outcome.

    Weinreich (phase 1/2, 8.0 g)

    Participants were centrally randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 522 out of 533 participants randomised.

    There is no information whether measurement of the outcome was appropriate, but it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the previous protocol. There is no indication that the outcome measurement and the results have been selected.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to the randomisation process, due to deviations from the intended interventions, missing outcomes and due to selection of reported results. However, there are some concerns for risk of bias due to measurement of the outcome.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 3.2 Adverse events: grade 3 and 4
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 3.3 Serious adverse events

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Weinreich (phase 1/2, 2.4 g)

    Participants were centrally randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 520 out of 532 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the previous protocol. There is no indication that the outcome measurement and the results have been selected.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    Weinreich (phase 1/2, 8.0 g)

    Participants were centrally randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 520 out of 532 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the previous protocol. There is no indication that the outcome measurement and the results have been selected.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 3.3 Serious adverse events
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 4.1 Mortality by day 30

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    COMET‐ICE

    Participants were randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were probably unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 583 out of 583 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was probably appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The trial protocol and SAP were not available. We have some concerns regarding selection of the reported results because the trial was stopped preliminary.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias from the randomization process, due to deviations from intended interventions, due to missing outcomes and due to measurement of the outcome. However, there are some concerns for bias due to selection of the reported results.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 4.1 Mortality by day 30
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 4.2 Development of severe symptoms according to WHO scale (≥ 5, incl. death)

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    COMET‐ICE

    Participants were randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were probably unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 583 out of 583 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was probably appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The trial protocol and SAP were not available. We have some concerns regarding selection of the reported results because the trial was stopped preliminary.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias from the randomization process, due to deviations from intended interventions, due to missing outcomes and due to measurement of the outcome. However, there are some concerns for bias due to selection of the reported results.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 4.2 Development of severe symptoms according to WHO scale (≥ 5, incl. death)

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    COMET‐ICE

    Participants were randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were probably unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 583 out of 583 participants randomised.

    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 4.6 Adverse events: all grades

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    COMET‐ICE

    Participants were randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were probably unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 868 out of 868 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was probably appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The trial protocol and SAP were not available. We have some concerns regarding selection of the reported results because the trial was stopped preliminary and the time point measured was not entirely clear.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias from the randomization process, due to deviations from intended interventions, due to missing outcomes and due to measurement of the outcome. However, there are some concerns for bias due to selection of the reported results.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 4.6 Adverse events: all grades

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    COMET‐ICE

    Participants were randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were probably unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 868 out of 868 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was probably appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The trial protocol and SAP were not available. We have some concerns regarding selection of the reported results because the trial was stopped preliminary and the time point measured was not entirely clear.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias from the randomization process, due to deviations from intended interventions, due to missing outcomes and due to measurement of the outcome. However, there are some concerns for bias due to selection of the reported results.

    Risk of bias for analysis 4.8 Serious adverse events

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    COMET‐ICE

    Participants were randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were probably unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 868 out of 868 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was probably appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The trial protocol and SAP were not available. We have some concerns regarding selection of the reported results because the trial was stopped preliminary and the time point measured was not entirely clear.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 4.8 Serious adverse events
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.1 Mortality by day 30

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Eom 2021 (40 mg/kg)

    Participants were randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the intervention received. Participants with a negative PCR were excluded from analysis in both groups (intervention and placebo group) and one participant in the placebo arm did not receive the allocated intervention. The analysis was probably appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 307 out of 327 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    Eom 2021 (80 mg/kg)

    Participants were randomised via an Interactive Web Response System (IWRS) and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the intervention received. Participants with a negative PCR were excluded from analysis in both groups (intervention and placebo group) and one participant in the placebo arm did not receive the allocated intervention. The analysis was probably appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 307 out of 327 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.1 Mortality by day 30
    Navigate to table in review

    Risk of bias for analysis 6.1 Mortality by day 30

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 314 out of 326 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.1 Mortality by day 30
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.2 Mortality by day 90

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 168 out of 168 participants with sustained recovery.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Data for this outcome was available for 314 out of 326 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.7 Adverse events: grade 3 and 4 by day 30
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.8 Serious adverse events by day 30

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 314 out of 326 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.8 Serious adverse events by day 30
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.9 Serious adverse events (90 day follow‐up)

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 168 out of 168 participants with sustained recovery.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.9 Serious adverse events (90 day follow‐up)

    Risk of bias for analysis 6.10 Sustained recovery (90 day follow‐up)

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for 314 out of 326 participants randomised.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.10 Sustained recovery (90 day follow‐up)
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.11 Neurological dysfunction by day 30: transient ischemic events

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data of 17 participants in the treatment arm and of 16 participants in the control arm were missing. The study was double‐blinded and it is not likely that missingness in the outcome depended on its true value.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.11 Neurological dysfunction by day 30: transient ischemic events
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.12 Neurological dysfunction by day 30: acute delirium CVA

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data of 17 participants in the treatment arm and of 16 participants in the control arm were missing. The study was double‐blinded and it is not likely that missingness in the outcome depended on its true value.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data of 17 participants in the treatment arm and of 16 participants in the control arm were missing. The study was double‐blinded and it is not likely that missingness in the outcome depended on its true value.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.14 Thromboembolic events by day 30

    Risk of bias for analysis 6.15 Renal dysfunction (or need for dialysis) by day 30

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    ACTIV‐3

    Participants were randomised via mass‐weighted urn randomisation. There are baseline differences, but they are unlikely to suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data of 17 participants in the treatment arm and of 16 participants in the control arm were missing. The study was double‐blinded and it is not likely that missingness in the outcome depended on its true value.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.15 Renal dysfunction (or need for dialysis) by day 30
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.1 Mortality by day 30

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    RECOVERY

    Participants were randomised via web‐based randomisation and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received and nearly all participants received assigned intervention. The analysis was appropriate. Because of no standard treatment for COVID‐19, control group may have received concomitant treatment more quickly.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 9785 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. It was unclear whether outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed and reported as planned in the protocol and SAP.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to the randomisation process, due to missing outcomes, due to measurement of the outcome and due to selection of reported results. However, there is high risk of bias due to deviations from the intended interventions.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.1 Mortality by day 30
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.2 Development of severe symptoms: requirement for IMV or death by day 28 (WHO ≥ 7)

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    RECOVERY

    Participants were randomised via web‐based randomisation and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received and nearly all participants received assigned intervention. The analysis was appropriate. Because of no standard treatment for COVID‐19, control group may have received concomitant treatment more quickly.

    Data for this outcome was available for 9198 out of 9785 participants randomised. 587 participants were on mechanical ventilation at randomisation and therefore excluded.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. It was unclear whether outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed and reported as planned in the protocol and SAP.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to the randomisation process, due to missing outcomes, due to measurement of the outcome and due to selection of reported results. However, there is high risk of bias due to deviations from the intended interventions.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.2 Development of severe symptoms: requirement for IMV or death by day 28 (WHO ≥ 7)
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.3 Hospital discharge alive by day 30

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    RECOVERY

    Participants were randomised via web‐based randomisation and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received and nearly all participants received assigned intervention. The analysis was appropriate. Because of no standard treatment for COVID‐19, control group may have received concomitant treatment more quickly.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 9785 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. It was unclear whether outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The outcome was pre‐specified and there is no indication for selective reporting.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to the randomisation process, due to missing outcomes, due to measurement of the outcome and due to selection of reported results. However, there is high risk of bias due to deviations from the intended interventions.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.3 Hospital discharge alive by day 30
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.4 Thromboembolic events by day 30

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    RECOVERY

    Participants were randomised via web‐based randomisation and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received and nearly all participants received assigned intervention. The analysis was appropriate. Because of no standard treatment for COVID‐19, control group may have received concomitant treatment more quickly.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 9785 participants randomised.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. It was unclear whether outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed and reported as planned in the protocol and SAP.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to the randomisation process, due to missing outcomes, due to measurement of the outcome and due to selection of reported results. However, there is high risk of bias due to deviations from the intended interventions.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.4 Thromboembolic events by day 30
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.5 Renal dysfunction (or need for dialysis) by day 30

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    RECOVERY

    Participants were randomised via web‐based randomisation and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received and nearly all participants received assigned intervention. The analysis was appropriate. Because of no standard treatment for COVID‐19, control group may have received concomitant treatment more quickly.

    Data for this outcome was available for 9670 out of 9785 participants randomised. Participants on renal replacement therapy at randomisation were therefore excluded.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. It was unclear whether outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed and reported as planned in the protocol and SAP.

    For this outcome, there is a low risk of bias due to the randomisation process, due to missing outcomes, due to measurement of the outcome and due to selection of reported results. However, there is high risk of bias due to deviations from the intended interventions.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.5 Renal dysfunction (or need for dialysis) by day 30
    Navigate to table in review
